attributes.action: Protect private companies and pension funds by closing Companies Act loopholes.
attributes.background: Under s172 Companies Act 2006, directors must "promote the success of the company" taking into account the long term consequences and the need to act fairly with stakeholders, such as employees.  However, Part 23 of the Act fails to prevent the asset-stripping of companies by the unscrupulous.
attributes.additional_details:
Accumulative distributable reserves should be restricted to cover the current pension fund deficit before further distributions are considered. 

Fixed assets should be recorded at fair value before assets are transferred out of the company and the non-distributable revaluation reserve created should remain with the company.

Non-distributable reserves converted to distributable reserves should be accounted for as unrealized profit for dividend purposes and not appropriated from the company.

attributes.action: Make all cyclists wear helmets and have insurance cover a legal requirement.
attributes.background: All cyclists should have to wear an approved standard helmet to reduce head injury if they come off their bikes.  They should also have to have insurance cover in case they damage, injure a third party or other vehicle. As at present there is no easy method to get a cyclist to pay for damage caused.
attributes.additional_details: Cyclist need to be protected from themselves in the same way that drivers were protected from themselves by the introduction of safety laws  (wearing seat belts). This would reduce deaths and the cost of health care levied on the NHS.  Cyclist should have insurance cover to ride on the road so if they inadvertently cause damage to another vehicle or person, then that person or vehicle damaged will have a simple method of recovering damages without having to go through a costly legal process.

attributes.action: Make the UK higher education system work like the US education system
attributes.background: In the first two years of study, in the American higher education system, you will generally be required to take a wide variety of classes in different subjects. I feel this is better than picking what you want to study ahead of going to university because you get a more rounded education.
attributes.additional_details:
One criticism of the American system is that teaching is more superficial than in UK higher education. I would argue, however, that students will gain a more rounded education this way. 

My reference for the way the HE system works in America is: https://www.studyusa.com/en/a/58/understanding-the-american-education-system

My reference for the American system being more superficial is: https://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/blog/2014/jun/30/uk-universities-better-education-dont-be-seduced-by-us

attributes.action: Scrap or Re-evaluate Hazard Perception
attributes.background:
The 'hazard perception' part of UK theory tests is one of the most hated parts of becoming a learner driver. 
The hazard perception part is taken on a computer, where you click the screen when you see a developing hazard.
attributes.additional_details:
The problem with this part of the theory test is that you have to spot 'developing hazards', and if you spot a hazard 'too early' you do not get the marks. Put this into real life, spotting a hazard too early? The entire marking scheme is pathetic. 
I do not disagree with the idea however, as spotting hazards is essential for safe driving. The hazard perception should be incorporated in the practical test and marked by an examiner, someone able to think, and not a computer.

attributes.action: Replace credit card commission to businesses with flat fees per transaction
attributes.background: The government announced recently that businesses are no longer able to charge commission on credit card payments. However, credit card companies can still levy commission on businesses. This is damaging to many businesses, especially as commissions vary, so we must introduce fixed fees instead.
attributes.additional_details:
More people will use a credit card rather than a debit card now there is no commission to pay. This is to be expected, after all, the money is better in their account for a month, but the cost to business is unjust.
The cost for debit card transactions is around 15p per transaction. 
For £100,000 worth of transactions at an average of £50, this would equate to £300. 
For credit cards this could be between £1,500 and £2,000. There is no justification for such excess so please help to stop it.

attributes.action: Referenda enacted by a UK nation must allow citizens born in that nation a vote.
attributes.background: If a UK nation considers a referendum about independence from the union, or a related topic that affects the stability of that union, then voters born in that nation, and who are citizens of the UK residing within the UK, must be able to vote on the referendum topic.
attributes.additional_details:
The Scottish Independence Referendum of 2014 refused the vote to citizens of the UK born in Scotland, but who resided in another nation of the UK. Since this would likely impact their citizenship (stateless?) and ability to work, they should be able to vote.

This is a general petition, and is not specific to a future Scottish Referendum. Any citizen of the UK, born in a UK nation (Northern Ireland, Wales, Scotland, England) where their birth-Nation has a referendum, should be able to vote.

attributes.action: Add American Football to the curriculum
attributes.background: Although American Football is not common in the U.K. Just yet, it is growing into interest to many people. However many people are restricted from playing it as there are very few clubs and no schools I know of includes American Football in there education.
attributes.additional_details: There are many benefits of playing American Football. The best thing about American Football is that anyone and everyone can play it as size doesn't matter. In fact being slightly overweight or being skinny can actually benefit to many people's attention. Many people think that American Football is a very rough sport but this is not true. You have contact American Football and you have Flag American Football meaning that if you play the flagged version there will be no contact meaning no harm

attributes.action: Law to be introduced so that members of the Emergency Services are served first.
attributes.background: Members of the Emergency Services work long and stressful hours. Often they will stop at a food establishment at the end of or during a shift. To be faced by a long queue when they just want to get home or get some refreshment. They may get a call-out while queuing so go without food or drink.
attributes.additional_details: A new law needs to be introduced. So that members of the Emergency Services in uniform always get served first at food establishments before other Customers.

attributes.action: Dart Charge penalty should be reduced to only £10 after 28 days, not £70.
attributes.background: Dart Charge used to be  £1 with members manning the toll gates. There was a big rise to the charge of almost 150%. Now fining motorists for failing to pay £2.50 resulting in £70 bill is unacceptable and should be abolished.

attributes.action: Digital Software libraries should be considered to be assets.
attributes.background: Digital Software is everywhere in today's world, this why the UK should be the first country to consider any form of digital software to an asset to the purchaser of that digital software whether it being Operating Systems, Video Games, Music & General Digital Software.
attributes.additional_details:
It has recently come about thanks to video game journalist Chris Bratt that digital software libraries are not considered to be assets and can not be transferred to a loved one if you sadly pass away. Furthermore, when you do sadly pass away these digital libraries of software get deleted wiping all monetary value from them as the terms of service are no longer valid.  

For further information watch Chris Bratt video here.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kHLFUbU5ceI

attributes.action: Abolish the 60% stealth income tax
attributes.background: The effective income tax rate for earnings of £100,000 - £123,000 is 60%, as the tax free allowance drops away. So the tax rate goes from 40% for earnings under £100,000, up to 60%, and then back down to 40% for earnings between £123,000 and £150,000. Truly bizzare.
attributes.additional_details: This tax rate is a clear disincentive for those earning around £100,000 (mainly those seen as "wealth creators"). So much so that the vast majority will surely act to avoid this rate (e.g. By paying into their pensions). This is dragging liquidity away from the market and therefore adversely affecting everyone in the country.

attributes.action: Teach Self-defense as a national curriculum
attributes.background: offer free self-defense lessons for free for children under the age of 18. This will possibly help with bullying and improve fitness

attributes.action: Make all companies share their maternity and paternity leave policies publically
attributes.background: Many companies provide maternity leave pay above the statutory minimum and increasing numbers also offer enhanced paternity pay. These can be invaluable for employees thinking about starting or growing their family but it's often a benefit you can't find out about when you sign up for a new job.
attributes.additional_details:
Making these policies publically available would help working parents make an informed choice about which companies they want to work for and help to celebrate the companies which are the most family friendly. It would also start to bring some parity to an area of benefits which at the moment varys widely from a couple of weeks full pay to a whole year. 

Having a child is one of life's most expensive adventures and choosing an employer who supports this shouldn't be left to chance or hearsay.

attributes.action: Add a coat of arms to the Union Flag, to better represent all nations of the U.K
attributes.background: Though iconic, the flag's design doesn't represent all of the United Kingdom. There is historical context for the omission of Wales, but if we truly are a Union of four countries, we need to show that to the world. Adding a coat of arms with four national symbols would be small, but significant.
attributes.additional_details:
In these times, the importance of the Union has been highlighted by figures across the political spectrum. 

Adding a small coat of arms to the Union Flag comprising of four symbols for each of the nations (Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland and England), would not change the issues the Union faces. But it might help restore confidence, and finally give Wales visual representation. 

It would be seen internationally, as well. A reminder, to us and to the world, that we are four nations - united.

attributes.action: Urge the British Government to recognise the Armenian tragedy as a genocide
attributes.background: I believe that my country was a beacon of hope and righteousness (being a descendant of holocaust survivors), but knowing that this is such an injustice has made me feel so utterly depressed that I no longer feel pride for my country, as it takes trade deals with Turkey over British moral principles
attributes.additional_details: https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/359550/FOI_ref_0298-14_Attachment_29.pdf

attributes.action: Stop involvement in the Afghan, Syrian and Iraqi Wars and bring troops home
attributes.background: Our involvement as the UK to stop the ongoing wars is the problem.  People are unhappy that we are continuously involved in the different wars and spending too much money on the wars when we could spend it on something useful in the UK. This is a major problem and could assist other campaigns
attributes.additional_details: We are spending a net amount of at least £20.3 billion just until 2010 (combined of only the cost of the afghan and Iraqi war).Many sources state that we are spending at least 37 billion by 2017 a statement by guardian stated “By 2020, Britain will have spent at least £40bn on its Afghan campaign, enough to recruit over 5,000 police officers or nurses and pay for them throughout their careers. It could fund free tuition for all students in British higher education for 10 years."

attributes.action: Ban the sale of foie gras throughout the UK when we leave the EU
attributes.background: Foie gras production has been banned in the U.K. so it seems hypocritical to still be able to sell foie gras. Now that we're leaving the EU, we should stop selling it.

attributes.action: To arm all police officers with handguns
attributes.background: I believe all police officers should be armed with handguns for officers protection. Over the last 2 years terror attacks have become increasingly regular and some could have been stopped with a simple shot from an officer. It will add security to the job of law enforcement and act as a deterrent
attributes.additional_details: In America it has been seen that police can be attacked and that a handgun can prevent that. It can also bring an end to criminal situations much faster.

attributes.action: Don’t ban Grouse Shooting
attributes.background: Protect Grouse Shooting
attributes.additional_details:
Grouse moors and grouse shooting are integral and traditional parts of moorland management which benefit the grouse and ALL native wildlife i.e. Lapwing and plovers. Grouse shooting is supported by the Royal family and real country people.
 
Grouse shooting income is essential for local businesses and jobs and should not be banned. Killing vermin is a social service which benefits ALL wildlife. Birds of prey are over-protected and are out of balance with natural habitats and species.

attributes.action: Reduce the tax on cigarettes and return cigarettes to old packaging
attributes.background: I don't think I need to explain the price hikes that have gone on in recent years on cigarettes, but the announcement of Phillip Hammond wanting to Raise prices again is a step to far, I suggest in this petition to remove all pre tax on cigarettes so they are just the 20% sales tax as standard
attributes.additional_details: Akin to this is the packaging rule which has caused problems throughout UK supermarkets of tellers handing customers wrong brands then refusing exchanges, is there any evidence that this reduces smoking in youth? Because I have seen no difference

attributes.action: Ban all plastic shopping bags and instead only sell reusable shopping bags.
attributes.background: The impact of plastic bags on the environment is enormous. ... Approximately 100,000 sea turtles and other marine animals die every year because they either mistake the bags for food or get strangled in them, says Natural.
attributes.additional_details:
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/nov/03/dramatic-rise-in-plastic-seabed-litter-around-uk
https://www.google.co.uk/amp/s/greenerideal.com/news/environment/0613-how-do-plastic-bags-affect-our-environment/amp/

attributes.action: Review eligibility date for Officers to get Long Service & Good Conduct medal.
attributes.background: I have recently discovered that Army Officer serving since 2014 will be issued with a Long Service and Good Conduct medal. I view this is a slap in the face for former Officers, such as my father, who served prior to the 2014 deadline, who is still alive, and spent 35 years in the British Army.
attributes.additional_details: I am aware of many former Officers who served full careers with the British Army and left without receiving a medal of any sort.  It would be a great honour for them to receive such an award after 15+ years of unblemished military service.  I would therefore wish for the eligibility date to be extended to those Officers who have served 15+ years since 1900, with the ability for their offspring to apply for the award.

attributes.action: Set up a UK Sovereign Wealth Fund
attributes.background:
The shale gas industry could give the UK an opportunity to do things better this time and put those funds aside for future generations.

Rather than investing in Gilts - pension companies should encourage investment in this fund to be used for major infrastructure  opportunities.
attributes.additional_details: Instead of squandering future revenue from this initiative like we did with oil in the 1970’s - invest the lot and build up a capital sterling reserve.

attributes.action: Pass legislation for the use of indelible ink pens mandatory for ALL elections.
attributes.background: In an age where pens are as cost effective as pencils, there is no excuse why the use of indelible ink pens should not be made mandatory. Old arguments on cost and potential for ink to smudge are not relevant today. However, a perception votes cast using a pencil can be manipulated, is a concern.

attributes.action: Firms that offer tax avoidance services should not win public sector contracts
attributes.background: As seen in the 'Panama' and 'Paradise' papers, wealthy clients use the services of lawyers and accountants to legally minimise tax obligations. Farcically, the major accounting/consulting firms often support the Government in drafting the same tax legislation they subsequently help clients avoid.

attributes.action: Make national rugby accessible to all to watch
attributes.background:
Home nation rugby should be available to all through live coverage on terrestrial tv channels.
It is absurd that one of our home nation teams playing one of our most popular sports is now only available to those who can afford to, and pre-plan to use subscription television.
attributes.additional_details: How can we be expected to support & celebrate our own nation in a sport in which we are world class when we are unable to watch without subscribing? The move of national sport from terrestrial TV to subscription services is going to gradually quench the ability for supporters to follow their nation & ultimately reduce participation in the sport. Not only will this reduce the passion for our nation but reduce any future prospects for a world leading team when we are at the very peak of the game.

attributes.action: Make sure we get a Brexit Deal.
attributes.background: If Brexit didn't have a deal, it would be chaos for us. If we can't get a  deal, we're on our own, and we'll have to rely on other countries to give us power and maybe being the end of the UK altogether. So there must be a Brexit deal, or we're in anarchy.

attributes.action: Change laws for British citizenship so they refer to ‘parent’ not ‘father’.
attributes.background:
The right to British citizenship depends on a number factors but sometimes, just the father.

An example is seen here: https://www.gov.uk/register-british-citizen/born-before-2006-british-father.

There is no need for gender at all.

attributes.action: Make food labels clearly state if the product is suitable for vegetarians.
attributes.background: With an estimated 2% of the population of Britain being vegetarian, many people will know the stuggle of scanning through every ingredient on a label trying to work out if they are able to eat the product. With this information so easily known to the manufacturers, it is time for this burden to end.
attributes.additional_details: I have been a vegetarian for over 10 years now and have constantly had trouble while shopping to see if I can actually eat the food on the shelves. I have even had to use my phone in store and search online for this simple answer, and many other families will know this struggle. When it looks like half of the ingredients on food labels now are chemicals I've never even heard of, it seems illogical for the consumer to have to go out of their way to find a simple, but essential, yes or no answer.

attributes.action: To made possible to claim disability discrimination when applying for a school.
attributes.background: Currently, the law prevents to make an appeal on disability discrimination case against Local Authority when they fail to secure a place at chosen school. The decision is made by Local Authority and SEND Tribunal can only act aginst schools.
attributes.additional_details: Under Schedule 17 of the Equality Act, 2010 Tribunal Special Educational Needs and Disability only has the power to consider a claim against the responsible body for school and cannot consider a claim against the local authority for the exercise of powers to determine the admission. The decision about child admission is made by local authority only and if the process is not correct parents cannot pursuit claim of disability discrimination against the local authority.

attributes.action: Scrap the OISC and extend the remit of the SRA to Immigration Advisers
attributes.background: The Office of Immigration Services Commissioner (OISC) is sponsored by the Home Office and regulates immigration advisers, professionals that do an important job and many are more specialised than solicitors. I believe the OISC operates in a secretive, undemocratic, biased and unfair manner.
attributes.additional_details:
It's powers are hardly challenged as it has many powers.

The fact this body quietly operates with professionals that do not have much legal knowledge can leave professionals open to unfair treatment. Surprisingly they almost always win cases in court. This cannot be right. The Home Office itself with much more infrastructure does not have this level of precision.

attributes.action: Require online retailers and platforms to disclose courier before order placed
attributes.background: When ordering goods online, websites generally do not state which courier service they will use for delivery. However, several courier companies have a track record of poor customer service and losing/damaging parcels. If consumers know which courier will be used, they can choose not to order.
attributes.additional_details: For an example, view the "tweets and replies" at @myhermes

attributes.action: Abolish business rates and replace with business rates transaction charge
attributes.background: Internet based companies have an unfair competitive advantage over traditional bricks and mortar retailers who have to pay business rates.  These disproportionate business rates are contributing towards the demise and failure of the local high street.   Help redress the imbalance for all retailers.
attributes.additional_details:
A 0.5% business rates charge levied on the sales value of each transaction would be a fair arrangement and would be linked directly to the success of a retail business. 
Since most sales transactions for online and high street retailers are by credit card, the collection mechanism is already in place.  The credit card holder’s physical location or credit card address is readily available for government’s re-distribution to the local authorities.
